title: Daniel Onega
text:
Daniel Onega (born March 17, 1945) is a retired <a href="Argentina">Argentine</a> <a href="football%20%28soccer%29">football</a> player who played most of his career for <a href="Club%20Atl%C3%A9tico%20River%20Plate">River Plate</a>. He also played for the <a href="Argentina%20national%20football%20team">Argentina national team</a> between 1966 and 1972. He is the brother of the late <a href="midfielder">midfielder</a> <a href="Ermindo%20Onega">Ermindo Onega</a>.
Onega started his career at <a href="Club%20Atl%C3%A9tico%20River%20Plate">River Plate</a>. It was with River Plate that he became the topscorer in the 1966 <a href="Copa%20Libertadores">Copa Libertadores</a> with 17 goals, setting the record for the most goals ever scored in a single season in that tournament, a record that has never been surpassed. He is also the 4th in the all time Copa Libertadores topscorers list with 31 goals in 47 games.
In 1972 Onega moved to <a href="Racing%20Club%20de%20Avellaneda">Racing Club</a> for a season, but he only managed 9 goals and returned to River the following season.
In 1973, he moved to <a href="Spain">Spain</a> to play for <a href="C%C3%B3rdoba%20CF">Córdoba CF</a> in the <a href="Segunda%20Divisi%C3%B3n">Spanish 2nd division</a>, he stayed with the club until 1978 when he moved to <a href="Millonarios">Millonarios</a> in <a href="Colombia">Colombia</a>. It was with Millonarios that he won his first and only league title. At the end of the 1978 season Onega retired from football.
